title: 108_hr5148
content: The "Identity Management Security Act of 2004" is also known as the Act. It focuses on improving security for driver licenses and state identity documents. The Act includes definitions for various terms related to identity management and security. SEC. 101 of the "Identity Management Security Act of 2004" provides definitions for key terms such as driver's license, identification card, State, and Secretary. SEC. 102 outlines the minimum document requirements and issuance standards for federal recognition. Beginning 3 years after the enactment of this Act, Federal agencies cannot accept driver's licenses or identification cards from States unless they meet the minimum standards outlined in this section. The Secretary will determine State compliance based on certifications provided by the State. States must include specific data elements and features on each driver's license and identification card to meet these requirements. The minimum standards for driver's licenses and identification cards include the person's name, date of birth, gender, license number, photo, address, signature, security features, and machine-readable technology for law enforcement use. To meet the requirements for issuing a driver's license or identification card, a State must verify a photo identity document, date of birth, social security number, and proof of address. To comply with driver's license issuance requirements, a State must verify the validity of documents used for identification and not accept foreign documents except official passports. Additionally, the State must use technology to capture digital images of identity for driver licenses and identification cards. To comply with driver's license issuance requirements, a State must verify the validity of documents used for identification and use technology to capture digital images of identity for driver licenses and identification cards. Retain paper copies of source documents for a minimum of 7 years or images for 10 years. Mandatory facial image capture for each applicant and confirm renewing applicant's information effectively. Confirm social security numbers with the full number presented. To ensure compliance with driver's license issuance requirements, States must resolve discrepancies in identification, refuse licenses without confirmation of termination from another State, secure production locations and materials, mandate security clearances for personnel, and provide fraudulent document recognition training. Establish fraudulent document recognition training programs for employees issuing driver licenses and identification cards. To be eligible for financial assistance, states must participate in the Driver License Agreement to share driver license data. State motor vehicle databases must include driver license information and driver histories. Additionally, there are regulations against trafficking authentication features for false identification documents. Section 1028(a)(8) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include "false or actual authentication features". Grants may be provided to States to help them meet the minimum standards outlined in the title. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2005 through 2009 for this purpose. SEC. 106. AUTHORITY. The Secretary of Transportation, in consultation with the States, has the authority to issue regulations, certify standards, and grant extensions for deadlines related to driver licenses and identification cards. TITLE II--IDENTITY SECURITY OF VITAL RECORDS. SEC. 201. DEFINITIONS. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Homeland Security. The term "birth certificate" is defined as a certificate of birth for an individual who is a citizen or national of the United States at birth and whose birth is registered in the United States. It must be issued by a government agency or authorized custodian of record. An authenticated copy of an original birth certificate must be issued by a government agency or authorized custodian of record. The government will conduct a study on the security of birth certificates. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the security of birth certificates and other birth documentation used for identity proof. This study will assess parties involved in issuance, physical security features, fraudulent activity, and methods used by Federal agencies and States. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress within 1 year, with recommendations to improve the security of birth certificates and reduce fraudulent activity in both domestic and foreign cases. This includes enhancing physical security measures and establishing minimum standards for issuing parties. SEC. 203. ELIMINATING DUPLICATION OF VITAL RECORDS. The Secretary will provide grants to States to computerize birth and death records, match records within and among states, and note deaths on birth certificates based on record creation numbers. Authorization of Appropriations: The Secretary is authorized to appropriate necessary funds for fiscal years 2005 through 2009 to carry out the computerization of birth and death records among states.
